UI_visible_response: Read 18 web pagesView Page DetailsThe number of casualties during the Long March is difficult to determine precisely due to the complex nature of the event. However, it is generally estimated that out of the approximately 86,000 soldiers who set out on the Long March, only about 7,000 to 8,000 reached the final destination in Shaanxi. This means that the majority of the soldiers, around 78,000 to 79,000, did not complete the journey.The Battle of Xiangjiang River was particularly devastating, with more than 50,000 of the Red Army's 86,000 troops dying on the battlefield. Throughout the entire Long March, the Red Army fought more than 660 battles, and on average, three or four soldiers sacrificed their lives for every kilometer of the march.CopyTry AgainShare
traffic_visible_response: The number of casualties during the Long March is difficult to determine precisely due to the complex nature of the event. However, it is generally estimated that out of the approximately 86,000 soldiers who set out on the Long March, only about 7,000 to 8,000 reached the final destination in Shaanxi[^3^]. This means that the majority of the soldiers, around 78,000 to 79,000, did not complete the journey.The Battle of Xiangjiang River was particularly devastating, with more than 50,000 of the Red Army's 86,000 troops dying on the battlefield[^6^]. Throughout the entire Long March, the Red Army fought more than 660 battles, and on average, three or four soldiers sacrificed their lives for every kilometer of the march[^1^][^7^].
